moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 N: The Scotch opening -- already a pair of Knights have vanished.
moves.5... d6 6. Nc3 Nf6 7. Bg5 Be7 8. O-O-O O: Completing my development. Now the middle game begins.
moves.11... Qxe7 12. Kb1: To avoid any annoying checks on the diagonal.
moves.12... Be6 13. Bxe6 fxe6 14. f3: Solidifying my Pawn position. Material is even but I have control of more of the board.
More slow maneuvering. Both sides have doubled Rooks on a closed file.
moves.22... d5 23. exd5: I expected the routine recapture 23... NxP, keeping material even.
moves.23... c6 24. dxc6: Now I have a small edge AND a chance to swap off the heavy pieces, magnifying the Pawn up. This is the turning point of the game.
moves.24... Rd7xd2 25. Rxd2 Rxd2 26. Qxd2: Even after Black takes the advanced QBP, I'll still have a 3 to 2 Q-side majority. I plan to advance these Pawns and force one through to the 8th rank.
moves.26... Qc7 27. Ne4 Nxe4 28. fxe4: I'm shocked Black exchanged off the Knights. With every piece that vanishes my advantage of one Pawn is magnified, and we're down to just one piece each left.
moves.28... Qxc6 29. Qd5+: Make that zero. This move seals the win for me.
moves.29... Qxd5 30. exd5 Kf8 31. Kc2: Now it's just a matter of technique. Of course, I must centralize my King.
moves.31... Ke7 32. c4: Now the wall of Pawns prevents Black's K from approaching on the Q-side.
moves.34... g5 35. h3: I'm just waiting for Black to run out of Pawn moves.
moves.36... Kd7 37. Ke4: If Black's KP falls, the game is over. My Q-side pawns will decide things.
moves.37... Kd6 38. Kf5: The KP must now fall. Black resigns.
